protocol_name: High Molecular Weight genomic DNA from coral sperm
protocol_name_html: High Molecular Weight genomic DNA from coral sperm
description:
This protocol is based on that described by Blin and Stafford (1976).

 

Blin, N., Stafford, D., 1976. A general method for isolation of high molecular weight DNA from eukaryotes. Nucleic Acids Research. 3, 2303.

 

It uses RNAse and ProteinaseK follwed by phenol/Chlorofrom extraction.  For the highest molecular weight, the DNA is purified by dialysis, avoiding alcohol precipitation.

groups.group_name: MinION user group for high molecular weight DNA extraction from all kingdoms

status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

components.data: 1. Grind frozen sperm to a fine powder in liquid nitrogen using a pre-cooled mortar and pestle.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 1. Grind frozen sperm to a fine powder in liquid nitrogen using a pre-cooled mortar and pestle.

components.data: 2. Add 10mls of lysis buffer (10mM Tris pH 8; 100mM EDTA; 0.5%SDS) per gram of starting material to the frozen powder and mix.  Due to the sub-zero temperature of the mortar, the mixture quickly freezes.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 2. Add 10mls of lysis buffer (10mM Tris pH 8; 100mM EDTA; 0.5%SDS) per gram of starting material to the frozen powder and mix.  Due to the sub-zero temperature of the mortar, the mixture quickly freezes.

components.data: 3. Allow the mixture to thaw - mix gently with the pestle while thawing to ensure even dispersion of the tissue through the lysis buffer.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 3. Allow the mixture to thaw - mix gently with the pestle while thawing to ensure even dispersion of the tissue through the lysis buffer.

components.data: 4. Place the thawed mixture in a 50 ml Falcon tube and add RNaseA (DNase-free) to 20 micrograms/ml
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 4. Place the thawed mixture in a 50 ml Falcon tube and add RNaseA (DNase-free) to 20 micrograms/ml

components.data: 5. Incubation at 37°C for 1 hour with periodic gentle mixing.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 5. Incubation at 37°C for 1 hour with periodic gentle mixing.

components.data: 6. Add Proteinase K to a concentration of 100 micrograms/ml and incubate at 50°C for 3 hours with periodic gentle mixing.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 6. Add Proteinase K to a concentration of 100 micrograms/ml and incubate at 50°C for 3 hours with periodic gentle mixing.

components.data: 7. Add an equal volume of phenol/chloroform/isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) and gently rotate end over end for 10 minutes at room temperature.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 7. Add an equal volume of phenol/chloroform/isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) and gently rotate end over end for 10 minutes at room temperature.

components.data: 8. Centrifuge at 5000g for 15 minutes at room temperature.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 8. Centrifuge at 5000g for 15 minutes at room temperature.

components.data: 9. Transfer the aqueous phase to a fresh 50ml falcon tube.  The aqueous phase can be very viscous and difficult to handle- sacrifice yield for purity.  If needed MaxTract High density (Qiagen) can be used to aid phase separation – this may require addition of extra chloroform.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 9. Transfer the aqueous phase to a fresh 50ml falcon tube.  The aqueous phase can be very viscous and difficult to handle- sacrifice yield for purity.  If needed MaxTract High density (Qiagen) can be used to aid phase separation – this may require addition of extra chloroform.

components.data: 10. Repeat the phenol/chloroform/isoamyl alcohol extraction twice and follow by an extraction using phenol/chloroform.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 10. Repeat the phenol/chloroform/isoamyl alcohol extraction twice and follow by an extraction using phenol/chloroform.

components.data: 11. Precipitate the DNA by adding 1/9th volume 3M sodium acetate pH5.2 and 0.6 volumes of isopropanol.  Mix gently until the DNA comes out of solution.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 11. Precipitate the DNA by adding 1/9th volume 3M sodium acetate pH5.2 and 0.6 volumes of isopropanol.  Mix gently until the DNA comes out of solution.

components.data: 12. If the yield is high enough, remove the DNA using a sealed glass pasteur pipette, or a Gilson tip and place in a large volume of 70% ethanol.  Mix gently for 5 minutes at room temperature.  Repeat the 70% ethanol wash at least two times, either by transferring the DNA to fresh tubes of 70% ethanol, or by carefully removing the 70%  ethanol and replacing it with fresh 70% ethanol.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 12. If the yield is high enough, remove the DNA using a sealed glass pasteur pipette, or a Gilson tip and place in a large volume of 70% ethanol.  Mix gently for 5 minutes at room temperature.  Repeat the 70% ethanol wash at least two times, either by transferring the DNA to fresh tubes of 70% ethanol, or by carefully removing the 70%  ethanol and replacing it with fresh 70% ethanol.

components.data: 13. Collect the DNA using a sealed glass pasteur pipette/Gilson tip and allow to air-dry.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 13. Collect the DNA using a sealed glass pasteur pipette/Gilson tip and allow to air-dry.

components.data: 14. Place the DNA in an appropriate volume of 1XTE (if EDTA is a problem use 0.1XTE), allowing it to detach from the pasteur pipette/Gilson tip.  The yield should be >1mg per gram of starting material.  Place at 4 degC. The DNA may take a long time (hours/days to dissolve properly).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 14. Place the DNA in an appropriate volume of 1XTE (if EDTA is a problem use 0.1XTE), allowing it to detach from the pasteur pipette/Gilson tip.  The yield should be >1mg per gram of starting material.  Place at 4 degC. The DNA may take a long time (hours/days to dissolve properly).

components.data: 15. If the yield is not high enough to remove the DNA from the isopropanol precipitation with a pasteur pipette/Gilson tip, use standard centrifugation to pellet the DNA.  Wash at least two times with 70% ethanol.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 15. If the yield is not high enough to remove the DNA from the isopropanol precipitation with a pasteur pipette/Gilson tip, use standard centrifugation to pellet the DNA.  Wash at least two times with 70% ethanol.

components.data: 16. Alternatively, for very high molecular weight DNA, dialyse the aqueous phase from the final phenol/chloroform extraction extensively against 50mM Tris pH 8; 10mM EDTA until the OD 260/280 is >1.8 (several changes of buffer over at least two days).  If EDTA is a problem, change the dialysis solution to 0.1XTE.  The dialysis option should only be considered if the expected yield is high.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: 16. Alternatively, for very high molecular weight DNA, dialyse the aqueous phase from the final phenol/chloroform extraction extensively against 50mM Tris pH 8; 10mM EDTA until the OD 260/280 is >1.8 (several changes of buffer over at least two days).  If EDTA is a problem, change the dialysis solution to 0.1XTE.  The dialysis option should only be considered if the expected yield is high.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 16 of High Molecular Weight genomic DNA from coral sperm
source_data.protocol_name: High Molecular Weight genomic DNA from coral sperm
source_data.protocol_name_html: High Molecular Weight genomic DNA from coral sperm
source_data.annotation: Hi David, How do you dialyse DNA?
source_data.thread_text: Hi David, How do you dialyse DNA?
source_data.body: Hi David, How do you dialyse DNA?

comments.name: David Hayward
comments.comment_text:
Prepare dialysis tubing (Molecular weight cut-off 12-14 kD).
Boil the tubing for 10 minutes in 1 litre of 2% sodium bicarbontae; 1mM EDTA
Rinse well with deionized water.
Autoclave in deionized water.
Allow to cool before use.  The tubing can be stored in water at 4 degrees C.
Seal one end of the tubing with a dialysis clip.
Add the DNA and seal the other end with a dialysis clip.
Place the dialysis bag containing the DNA in 2 litres of 50mM Tris pH 8; 10mM EDTA.
Stir gently at 4 degrees C.
comments.body:
Prepare dialysis tubing (Molecular weight cut-off 12-14 kD).
Boil the tubing for 10 minutes in 1 litre of 2% sodium bicarbontae; 1mM EDTA
Rinse well with deionized water.
Autoclave in deionized water.
Allow to cool before use.  The tubing can be stored in water at 4 degrees C.
Seal one end of the tubing with a dialysis clip.
Add the DNA and seal the other end with a dialysis clip.
Place the dialysis bag containing the DNA in 2 litres of 50mM Tris pH 8; 10mM EDTA.
Stir gently at 4 degrees C.
